critique: This document is an executive order from 1933 that defers the effective date of certain provisions of a previous executive order. It relates to vocational education, agricultural programs, and the abolishment of the Federal Employment Stabilization Board. Given the context of the Great Depression and the New Deal, the document likely reflects a moderate level of government intervention in the economy. There is no direct indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, executive power expansion, national security concerns, or social inclusion issues. The federalism aspect is slightly tilted towards federal control as it involves federal programs and boards.
